text:
Flatbush Avenue, at the intersection of Washington Avenue, showing the Nelson Hotel. It was removed from its original site to a place which was once part of the old Clove Road.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection
about 1890

Flatbush Ave., west side, south of Maple Street, showing the Leffert's House, which was moved to Prospect Park in 1918. Now (1936) the "Cliff Hall Apartments" occupy the site.

1897.

A peanut vender near the junction of Washington and Flatbush Aves. This view is northwest. The building with the mansard roof is on Lincoln Road, Brooklyn.

About 1905.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Refreshments - Peanuts - Brooklyn.

text:
(1)

563 Flatbush Ave., east side, between Maple and Midwood Streets. The view shows the old Lefferts Homestead now removed to Prospect Park.

1914.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing the entrance to the home.

1914.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

1914.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing the entrance to the home.

1914.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

563 Flatbush Avenue, at the S. E. corner of Maple Street, showing the old Lefferts House. The house was later replaced by a 6-story apartment house, the Northcliff Hall.

About 1917

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

(1)
563 Flatbush Ave., east side, between Maple and Midwood Streets. This house clearly marked on the map of 1908 of Brooklyn. The view is the Lefferts Farmhouse, removed in 1918, to Prospect Park. It stood at 563 Flatbush Ave., upon which site is now the North Cliff Hall Apartments. It was built by Pieter Lefferts (1753-1791), on site of an earlier house (built 1666), destroyed in the Battle of Flatbush, during the Revolution.
1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
This is a post out of the Lefferts barn 112 years old, stood on the Canarsie Lane near Midwood Street. It was razed in 1904. It was built in 1792. 373-375 Midwood Street, occupy the site.
1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Flatbush Ave., west side, opposite Sullivan Street, showing Leffer's house in Prospect Park. It was moved from 563 Flatbush Ave., to the Park in 1918.
1922.

The same, another view.

(1)

582-590 Flatbush Ave., west side, between Beekman Place and Chester Court. No. 590 at the left, is the Thatcher House, the property of the J. Vanderbilt heirs. At the right, No. 582, was razed about 1928, to make way for the Patio Theatre.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing the south side of No. 590, the Thatcher House.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

598 Flatbush Ave., west side, between Beekman Place and Chester Court. This home is no longer in existence. (1936).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Flatbush Ave., east side, at Maple Street, showing the Judge Vanderbilt home, built in 1847. He passed away at the age of 58, in May 1877, and the property became that of Mrs. Lefferts Vanderbilt, who sold it in 1907, to a Realty concern.

1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, another angle.

1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

563-577 Flatbush Ave., east side, south of Maple Street. 577 is at the right; 563 at the S.E. corner of Midwood Street is in the center of the site formerly occupied by the Lefferts House.

May, 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
